author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Black Site’ Review: Stranger Danger
description: A murderous detainee and a damaged C.I.A. agent face off in this uninspired action movie.
content: Perhaps the most depressing thing about Sophia Banks’s “Black Site” — a dreary, underwritten thriller — is an ending that suggests a sequel might already be in the works. For the sake of its beleaguered star, Michelle Monaghan, I can only hope not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Inbetween Girl’ Review: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Woman
description: Mei Makino’s coming-of-age drama depicts an artsy, biracial high school student grappling with the guilt of sleeping with another girl’s boyfriend.
content: Angie Chen (Emma Galbraith) trudges through multiple gray areas in “Inbetween Girl,” an intelligent teenage drama by the writer and director Mei Makino.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: Deadly Venom From Spiders and Snakes May Cure What Ails You
description: Efforts to tease apart the vast swarm of proteins in venom — a field called venomics — have burgeoned in recent years, leading to important drug discoveries.
content: TUCSON, Ariz. — In a small room in a building at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, the invertebrate keeper, Emma Califf, lifts up a rock in a plastic box. “This is one of our desert hairies,” she said, exposing a three-inch-long scorpion, its tail arced over its back. “The largest scorpion in North America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: He Wrapped Landmarks in Fabric. Years Later, His Art Turned Up in a Dumpster.
description: Hundreds of paintings by Francis Hines had been thrown away when a Connecticut man, Jared Whipple, found them — and a new life mission.
content: The gauze-wrapped building towered over the East Village like a bandaged wound. It was May 1979 and the artist, Francis Hines, had covered an abandoned five-story tenement with 3,500 yards of white fabric, loosely sealing inside the littered drug needles and crumbled walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: N.Y.C. Lawyer Fired Over Handling of George Floyd Protesters’ Lawsuits
description: New York’s Law Department said it dismissed the lawyer after discovering she had made a misrepresentation in court filings.
content: Demonstrations in New York after the 2020 murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer led to a wave of lawsuits accusing the police of using excessive force and other abusive tactics that violated protesters’ rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: What Would the End of Roe Mean? Key Questions and Answers.
description: Abortion would remain legal in about half of states, but the rest would likely ban it. The number of abortions would probably fall, particularly among poor women in the South and Midwest.
content: A leaked Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade describes a United States not seen in half a century, in which the legal status of abortion is entirely up to the states. If the draft, from February and published Monday night by Politico, ends up being similar to the court’s final opinion, expected next month, reproductive rights will be rewritten almost immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Body From Decades-Old Homicide Is Found in Barrel at Lake Mead
description: “It’s really odd in the sense that had the lake never receded, we would never have discovered the body,” a police lieutenant in Las Vegas said, adding that it could also lead to the discovery of other bodies.
content: A metal barrel containing the remains of a person killed about four decades ago was found on Sunday on the shore of Nevada’s Lake Mead, a discovery that the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department said was made possible by an ongoing drought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and John Ismay
title: Biden, Visiting Missile Factory, Calls for Ramping Up U.S. Aid to Ukraine
description: The president’s call came as Republicans worried that the aid was harming U.S. military readiness and progressives fretted over his stalled domestic agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden made a forceful call on Tuesday for ramping up American military support for Ukraine as his administration rapidly dispenses artillery, antitank weapons and other hardware, raising questions about the surge in spending at a time when his domestic agenda is stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Kockenmeister
title: Lesson of the Day: The Math of Inflation
description: Prices are going up for everyone, but some feel the increase more than others. In this lesson, students will use mathematics to understand inflation and its unequal effects.
content: Featured Article: “Americans Say High Prices Are Hitting the Things They Need to Get By” by Emily Badger, Aatish Bhatia and Quoctrung Bui
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: The Nightmare of Being a Surrogate Mother in Wartime
description: Ukraine’s booming surrogacy business has become a logistical and ethical mess — and hell for the women at the center.
content: On Feb. 24, in the early hours of a cold, dark morning in Lviv, two phones in one apartment rang nearly simultaneously. The phones belonged to two women, Maryna and Nataliia, professional colleagues of a sort and temporary roommates; they were also newfound friends, both of them pregnant and near the beginning of their third trimesters. Just over a week earlier, they had come from Kyiv, where they’d both been living, on a kind of business trip. Lviv was around an eight-hour train ride away, a hassle of a journey even for someone who wasn’t pregnant, and it was especially unappealing in the heart of a freezing Ukrainian winter. But the American businesswoman who was working with them insisted — the clients demanded it. They would be away two weeks at the most, she’d told them. Their manager tried to sell it: See it as a paid vacation to Lviv! The town was well known to Ukrainians for its historic cobblestone streets and charming pastel townhouses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Swing on the Monkey Bars
description: Trust yourself. Falling is part of the process.
content: “You need to get a good swing going,” says Bella Palmer, 13, a competitor in all three seasons of “American Ninja Warrior Junior,” a program on Peacock based on a Japanese show called “Sasuke.” Last year, Palmer won the competition in the 11- and 12-year-old bracket, making her the show’s first female champion. Palmer’s favorite challenge in the contest is called Spring Forward, a sort of extreme monkey bars where the rungs are roughly six feet apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: In a Nod to Changing Norms, Smithsonian Adopts Policy on Ethical Returns
description: The institution’s leaders hope other cultural centers will follow its lead. It has already announced plans to return most of its collection of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria under the new policy.
content: The Smithsonian Institution announced Tuesday that it has adopted a policy that will formally authorize its constituent museums to return items from their collections that were looted or were otherwise once acquired unethically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: A new coronavirus surge sweeping Puerto Rico took hold soon after restrictions were lifted.
description: The island is reporting new cases at more than six times the national per-capita rate, and hospitalizations are rising.
content: The coronavirus is surging in Puerto Rico, with new cases being reported at a per-capita rate more than six times the national average. The spike began just five days after the island lifted all its pandemic restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Irving Rosenthal, Low-Profile Force on the Beat Scene, Dies at 91
description: He published Ginsberg, Kerouac and Burroughs in the late 1950s. The university that oversaw his journal was not pleased with the “Naked Lunch” excerpt.
content: Irving Rosenthal wasn’t famous like the Beat figures he associated with — Jack Kerouac, William S. Burroughs, Allen Ginsberg and others. But he was an integral part of their scene. In fact, he propelled it forward at a crucial time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Circle these dates on the midterm primary calendar.
description: Pennsylvania, North Carolina and Georgia are among the races to watch.
content: Ohio and Indiana mark the start of a particularly rugged stretch of the midterm election gantlet, one flush with bitter and costly primaries that will help determine control of Congress and governors’ offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: An America Without Roe v. Wade Will Be a Dark Place
description: The coming nightmare of illegal abortion.
content: A 26-year-old Texas woman named Lizelle Herrera was arrested and charged with murder last month following an alleged self-induced abortion. It was only after Herrera spent two days in jail and, amid a national uproar, was released on $500,000 bond that the local district attorney concluded she had committed no crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Hillary Clinton attends the Met Gala for the first time in two decades.
description: Hillary Clinton’s dress is making a statement: that shaping history is itself a form of glamour.
content: Hillary Clinton’s dress is making a statement: that shaping history is itself a form of glamour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Roe’s Fall Would Alter Political Battle Lines. But in What Way?
description: Democrats hope abortion rights will motivate the party’s base. Republican strategists are skeptical, though they are privately unsure how the issue might affect the midterms.
content: Democrats who were privately hoping for a surprise development to shake up the midterms have gotten their wish. Nobody expected it to come in the form of a leaked draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, however.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Do You Work at an Abortion Clinic?
description: We’re interested in hearing from people whose work may be directly affected by a Supreme Court reversal of Roe v. Wade.
content: If it becomes final, the Supreme Court’s draft ruling overturning Roe v. Wade that was leaked on Monday will alter the work of many organizations involved in abortion rights. That’s especially true in states that are likely to ban abortion, or where so-called trigger laws will do so automatically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: An Extraordinary Heat Wave Exposes the Limits of Protecting People
description: Temperatures are soaring across South Asia, testing dangerous thresholds. How much is climate change to blame? It’s becoming an ‘obsolete question,’ one scientist says.
content: A street hawker squatted on the sidewalk and struggled for breath. A construction worker moved slowly, careful not to pass out. A house painter was home sick, losing out on several day’s wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Russia Could Sell More Energy to Asia, but Has to Slash Prices
description: Russia wants to sell more oil and coal to China and India, but Western sanctions may make that hard unless Russia offers deep discounts on the price.
content: BEIJING — Last year, the Grand Aniva, a Russian tanker with four spherical tanks for holding ultracold liquefied natural gas, sailed back and forth between a gas field in eastern Russia and depots in Japan and Taiwan. But two days after Russia invaded Ukraine, the ship switched routes, sailing to China instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Invoking Churchill, Boris Johnson says the war is ‘Ukraine’s finest hour.’
description: In the first address by a foreign leader to Ukraine’s Parliament, Britain’s prime minister burnished his credentials as a supporter of the resistance to Russia.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers on Tuesday that their heroic defense against Russia’s invasion would rank as “Ukraine’s finest hour,” invoking Winston Churchill’s famous declaration about Britons as they faced the Nazi onslaught at the beginning of World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: When will we have results in Tuesday’s primary contests?
description: Every election night is different, and the timing of results can be downright messy. Here are factors at play in Ohio and Indiana.
content: As we have said before, predicting the timing of election results is not an exact science. It can be downright messy. And surely, every election night is different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Tim Ryan will be the Democrats’ nominee for Senate in Ohio.
description: Staying within a moderate lane focused on jobs, manufacturing and China, the congressman beat a progressive lawyer who had criticized his record and campaign donations.
content: Representative Tim Ryan cruised to victory in the Democratic primary election for Senate in his state, running in a moderate lane focused on tackling jobs, manufacturing and taking on China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Mooallem
title: The Matador and Me: Coming to Terms with My Famously Ugly Lookalike
description: What my resemblance to a Spanish bullfighter taught me about the dilemma beneath every human face.
content: One night, many years ago, two friends spotted something extraordinary hanging on the wall of a restaurant in Spain, and they knew, right away, that they’d need to send me a picture of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Reporting on an Unpredictable Deal
description: Lauren Hirsch, a Times business reporter, discusses what it’s been like to cover Elon Musk over the course of his acquisition of Twitter.
content: In April, Elon Musk, the world’s wealthiest man, set the wheels in motion for a dramatic arc when it was revealed that he had bought a 9.2 percent share of Twitter. Over the next several weeks, Mr. Musk was invited to join Twitter’s board, then reversed course, threatened a hostile takeover of the company and ultimately reached a deal to buy Twitter for roughly $44 billion last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Liverpool’s Dream Delivered, Only After Villarreal’s Is Dashed
description: Outplayed for a half, Liverpool scored three goals to reach its latest Champions League final. For Villarreal, though, all was not lost.
content: VILLARREAL, Spain — In the corner of the Estadio de la Céramica, the one left totally at the mercy of the elements, the fans started to unfurl their scarves. On the scoreboard at their backs, the clock had ticked beyond 90 minutes. On the field in front of them, Villarreal was on borrowed time in the Champions League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Do I Feel Sick Before My Period?
description: Researchers don’t fully understand the menstrual cycle’s effects on the immune system, but experts say there are reasons some may feel sick at certain points.
content: Q: Does a woman’s immune system weaken at certain times of her menstrual cycle? I have always noticed that if I get sick, it’s almost always just before I get my period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: Russia’s hesitation
description: Analysts are asking why the onslaught has not been even worse.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: It’s Time to Rage
description: We can’t let this country become a hollow theocracy.
content: My wife’s stepfather began raping her when she was 11 years old. The abuse went on for years, and as Debbie got older, she was constantly terrified that she was pregnant. She had no one to talk to and nowhere to turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP writes off $25.5 billion on its Russia pullout, but oil and gas profits soar.
description: The energy company said quarterly profit had more than doubled from a year earlier.
content: BP, the London-based energy giant, reported its highest profit in a decade on Tuesday. The company said its underlying replacement cost profits were $6.2 billion for the first quarter of 2022, more than double the $2.6 billion of a year earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Sarahbeth Maney
title: Demonstrators Gathered at Supreme Court Lament, and Celebrate, Leaked Draft
description: Armed with megaphones, signs, buttons and at least one letterpress for speedy poster production, groups supporting and opposing abortion rights demonstrated.
content: WASHINGTON — Scores of protesters took to the steps in front of the Supreme Court on Tuesday hours after a draft opinion overturning the landmark Roe v. Wade decision leaked. Armed with megaphones, signs, buttons and at least one letterpress for speedy poster production, groups supporting and opposing abortion rights demonstrated and occasionally confronted one another in front of the barricaded court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: A leaked draft opinion indicated that a seismic shift was imminent.
description: A leaked draft opinion indicating the Supreme Court has voted to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that guaranteed abortion access, sent immediate shock waves throughout the United States, as many Americans braced for a future without reproductive rights that had been established for nearly a half-century.
content: A leaked draft opinion indicating the Supreme Court has voted to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that guaranteed abortion access, sent immediate shock waves throughout the United States, as many Americans braced for a future without reproductive rights that had been established for nearly a half-century.

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 4 Recap: The Wicked Flee
description: Gus sweats life in red-alert mode while Jimmy goes on a joyride.
content: Gus Fring is getting nervous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Rob Stein, Who Changed How Politics Is Funded, Dies at 78
description: In the wake of Republican electoral victories in 2004, he convened major liberal donors to finance a network of political groups aligned with Democrats.
content: Rob Stein, a Democratic strategist who helped reshape American politics by pioneering new ways for wealthy liberals to influence policy debates and elections, died on Monday at a hospice facility in Washington. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: 9 important governor’s races happening this year.
description: The races for governor are likely to be noisy and in some of the most competitive states, the outcome has implications far beyond the governor’s mansion.
content: This November, voters in three dozen states will elect, or re-elect, their chief executive. Even before the candidate matchups are set, the contours of the debate in many of these races are clear. The races for governor are likely to be noisy, with fights over schools, managing the economy, residual Covid debates and race and gender politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: In Europe, Possible Roe Reversal Elicits Concern and Criticism
description: European countries have been moving toward more, not less, abortion access.
content: On Tuesday, news that the United States Supreme Court might overturn Roe v. Wade triggered criticism and concern across Europe, a continent that in recent decades has consistently moved toward freer access to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Overturning Roe Is a Radical, Not Conservative, Choice
description: An abrupt and profound change to an established law is utterly destructive to respect for the law.
content: Dear Chief Justice Roberts and Justices Barrett, Gorsuch, Kavanaugh and Thomas:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Sommelier Who Set Fire to Dining Sheds Agrees to Pay Back Restaurants
description: Caleb Ganzer, who had scaled the heights of the high-end wine trade, was caught on video setting fires. An agreement with prosecutors could result in charges against him being dismissed.
content: A sommelier charged last year with arson has reached an agreement with the Manhattan district attorney’s office that will require him to pay thousands of dollars to two downtown restaurants whose outdoor dining structures he set on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Statue of Star Native American Ballerina Is Stolen and Sold for Scrap
description: The Tulsa, Okla., police are looking for whoever cut down and sold parts of a statue of Marjorie Tallchief, a celebrated performer who died last year.
content: At the end of a row of statues in Tulsa, Okla., Marjorie Tallchief, a celebrated Native American ballerina, had stood ensconced in bronze, en pointe in a tutu, since 2007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Norman Y. Mineta, First Japanese American Cabinet Member, Dies at 90
description: Interned during World War II, he went to Congress and later served in the cabinets of Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.
content: Norman Y. Mineta, who as a boy was interned with his family and thousands of other Japanese Americans during World War II, then rose in government to become a 10-term Democratic congressman from California and a cabinet official under Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, died on Tuesday at his home in Edgewater, Md. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Jason Horowitz
title: Sensing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
description: ‘You have exploded the myth of Putin’s invincibility,’ Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers, one of several Western sources of cheerleading on Tuesday.
content: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — President Biden spoke in an Alabama factory that built the Javelin missiles Ukrainian soldiers used against Russian tanks. Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain addressed members of Ukraine’s Parliament, extolling their “finest hour.” President Emmanuel Macron of France pressed Russia’s Vladimir V. Putin by phone to end his “devastating aggression.” Germany helped Finland and Sweden — Russia’s Nordic neighbors once wary of provoking Mr. Putin — inch closer to joining NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Roe, on the Edge
description: Roe v. Wade seems to be on the cusp of falling.
content: The Supreme Court has decided to overturn Roe v. Wade and allow states to outlaw abortion, according to a written draft of the justices’ decision obtained by Politico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Megan Thee Stallion Is a Gilded ‘Hot Girl’
description: The story behind the red-carpet look.
content: “I love gold,” Megan Thee Stallion said on Saturday night, sitting in a makeup chair somewhere in Memphis, getting ready for a festival performance — a good thing, too, considering that 48 hours later, in New York, the rapper would attend her second Met Gala drenched in the stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: David Birney, Who Starred on TV’s ‘Bridget Loves Bernie,’ Dies at 83
description: The sitcom, about an interfaith marriage, drew criticism from Jewish groups and was canceled after one season. He fared better onstage than in television.
content: David Birney, a classically trained theater actor who found success on the stage, including on Broadway, but who was best known for his role in “Bridget Loves Bernie” — a short-lived sitcom about an interfaith marriage in which he starred opposite his future wife, Meredith Baxter — died on Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed, Melissa Eddy and Benjamin Novak
title: Europe Is About to Ban Russian Oil: What’s Next?
description: Policymakers want to stop financial support to a war machine. Replacing that energy supply is going to be difficult and expensive for consumers.
content: Russia’s decades-long dominance of Europe’s energy market is crumbling, and the biggest blow is expected this week as the European Union moves toward a ban on Russian oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Véronique Hyland
title: I’m a Fashion Editor, and I Shop at the Dump
description: I used to be ashamed of my secret. But I’m ready to come clean.
content: The plain black wicker bag between my knees bore no designer label, just a “Made in British Hong Kong” tag that dated it to the last millennium. Extravagantly sturdy, it had the air of what magazines might call an investment piece. When the friend sitting next to me at a New York Fashion Week event inquired about its provenance, I decided, for once, not to lie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Lucia Pizza Brings Roni Cups and Clam Pies to Sheepshead Bay
description: A new pizzeria in Brooklyn strays from the slice-shop template.
content: Walk into any pizzeria in New York City, with a few well-known exceptions, and you can order with your eyes closed: A thin-crust cheese slice is inevitable, a Sicilian or grandma slice is likely, an all-cheese white pie is probable. There will definitely be pepperoni, and because many owners buy from the same suppliers, the pepperoni you get in the Bronx this week will not be noticeably different from the pepperoni you had in Queens last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Bragg
title: The Racist Song That Has Dug Deep Roots in American Culture
description: Emily Bingham’s “My Old Kentucky Home” describes how a song that sentimentalized the slaveholding South became a kind of anthem.
content: MY OLD KENTUCKY HOMEThe Astonishing Life and Reckoning of an Iconic American SongBy Emily Bingham
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Making a Beautiful ‘Case for the Existence of God’
description: Samuel D. Hunter’s heartbreaking new play argues for hope even in the face of extreme disappointment.
content: About a third of the way through “A Case for the Existence of God,” Samuel D. Hunter’s must-see heartbreaker of a play, one character, Ryan, tells the other one, Keith, “I think we share a specific kind of sadness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Eric Adams makes a statement on the red carpet.
description: The mayor is attending the Met Gala for the first time.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City arrived at his first Met Gala wearing a tuxedo jacket with the words “End Gun Violence” written across the back, along with a drawing of a handgun encircled in a “no” symbol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosie Schaap
title: Songs of Innocence, Experience and a Galaxy Far, Far Away
description: In “William Blake vs. the World,” John Higgs examines the visionary poet’s relevance to modernity.
content: WILLIAM BLAKE VS. THE WORLDBy John Higgs
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Fraser
title: Faces Are Important. But I Can’t Recognize Them.
description: What does it mean to live with prosopagnosia? An animator discloses the different ways he lives his life because he can’t recognize faces.
content: When I was going through the diagnosis process for autism, it became apparent that I did not recognize faces. When I’d look at people’s faces, I would struggle to identify them — even if we had met before. This is commonly known as face blindness, or prosopagnosia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Black Twitter Is Not a Place. It’s a Practice.
description: The origins and meaning of Black Twitter.
content: On a typical day last week, my iPhone was logged into Twitter for over five hours. That puts me in the minority in the United States. In 2021, according to a Pew Research survey, only about a quarter of American adults use Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Met Gala
description: What did you think of this year’s theme and costumes?
content: Last night, the extravaganza known as the Met Gala, the annual benefit for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, was held in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Travis Dove
title: The Junior College Team Built by the Pandemic
description: The baseball team at Gaston College in Dallas, N.C., is in its first season and owes its quick rise to former Division I players whose circumstances changed because of the pandemic.
content: GASTONIA, N.C. — The recruiting pitch to play baseball at Gaston College required a vivid imagination last spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Robin Pogrebin
title: New York City Eliminates the Rules That Govern Art and Other Auctions
description: Auction houses like Sotheby’s and Christie’s will no longer need to be licensed as part of a sweeping package designed to promote a business-friendly climate.
content: New York City has eliminated the regulations it had tailored to govern the auction industry, an abrupt reversal in policy that is part of a sweeping effort to improve conditions for businesses after the economic damage brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dustin Illingworth
title: After a Five-Decade Run, a Master Hangs Up His Reins
description: In “Last Letter to a Reader,” Gerald Murnane closes an illustrious career with thoughts on each of his books.
content: “Please God,” the Australian writer Gerald Murnane wrote to himself in early 2010, “don’t let me get drawn into the writing of any more fiction.” The master had ostensibly retired in semi-obscurity 15 years earlier, in 1995, after his seventh book, “Emerald Blue,” had sold just 600 copies. But an unexpected return with the novel “Barley Patch” (2009) set in motion a flourishing late period — divine pleas be damned — including seven new books, a major award and persistent Nobel rumors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Schoch
title: Hydroponic Lettuce Was Seen as Safe From Salmonella, Until an Outbreak
description: The F.D.A. criticized measures at a hydroponics greenhouse linked to an outbreak last summer, and offered guidelines that have ramifications for the popular industry.
content: Countless salad lovers have embraced hydroponic produce, confident that baby lettuce, arugula and herbs raised indoors in greenhouses are safer than greens rooted outdoors in farm soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Spring Awakening: Those You’ve Known’ Review: Rock ’n’ Roll High School
description: This film about the hit 2006 musical is a sure-handed blend of making-of explainer, theater-kid scrapbook, and jukebox documentary.
content: The winner of eight Tonys in 2007 including best musical, “Spring Awakening” now gets an adoring documentary for a victory lap celebration. “Spring Awakening: Those You’ve Known” does a suitably wide-eyed recap of the show’s success, on the occasion of a recent reunion concert with the endearingly jazzed cast. Michael John Warren’s film is a sure-handed blend of making-of explainer, theater-kid scrapbook and jukebox documentary, doling out hits from its theatrical run (through clips) and the reunion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
description: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
content: Russia’s war against Ukraine has leveled cities, killed tens of thousands of people and forced millions of others from their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac, Cade Metz and Kate Conger
title: ‘I Don’t Really Have a Business Plan’: How Elon Musk Wings It
description: To a degree unseen in any other mogul, the world’s richest man acts on impulse and the belief that he is absolutely right.
content: As Twitter negotiated a sale to Elon Musk last month, the social media company pulled out a corporate takeover playbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Evacuees From Mariupol’s Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
description: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
content: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — Some flashed bright smiles and others bent over in heaving sobs, sharing the end of their hellish subterranean ordeal. Here, at last, were ordinary things they thought they might not live to see again: sunlight, enough food and escape from incessant Russian shelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: An evacuation from Mariupol.
content: Civilians evacuated from Mariupol, Ukraine, described scenes of survival and terror, saying they had subsisted on Russian rations cooked outside on wood fires amid daily shelling that left corpses lying in debris. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Get Ready for Another Energy Price Spike: High Electric Bills
description: Rates have jumped because of a surge in natural gas prices and could keep rising rapidly for years as utilities invest in electric grids.
content: Already frustrated and angry about high gasoline prices, many Americans are being hit by rapidly rising electricity bills, compounding inflation’s financial toll on people and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Right-Wing Twitter Exiles Weigh a Return to the Arena
description: Elon Musk’s plans to buy the social media platform were met with glee by some on the right. But will they all come back?
content: News of Elon Musk’s planned acquisition of Twitter last week was the sort of thing that Bill Mitchell would once have tweeted about to his six-digit audience of Twitter followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: The Era of Cheap and Plenty May Be Ending
description: Supplies of goods are coming up short in the pandemic, and prices have jumped. Some economists warn that the changes could linger.
content: For the past three decades, companies and consumers benefited from cross-border connections that kept a steady supply of electronics, clothes, toys and other goods so abundant it helped prices stay low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The End of Roe?
description: Abortion is in jeopardy in the U.S.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court confirmed the authenticity of a leaked draft ruling that would overturn the Roe v. Wade decision, which established a constitutional right to abortion almost 50 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Boncompagni
title: And Now, the $200,000 Face-Lift
description: Luxury cosmetic procedures reach next level prices.
content: As the famous F. Scott Fitzgerald line goes, the rich are different from you and me — and apparently so, too, are their face-lifts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How companies have handled restrictive abortion laws.
description: A leaked Roe v. Wade draft ruling could raise pressure on business leaders to take a stand.
content: With Roe v. Wade on the verge of being overturned, according to a draft Supreme Court ruling obtained by Politico on Monday night, business leaders are likely to face greater pressure to address the state of abortion access.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: U.S. job openings hit a high point, 11.5 million, in March.
description: New government data suggests that the economy remains far from normal as employers struggle to fill jobs and workers seek better positions.
content: A government survey released Tuesday showed a record number of job openings, with 11.5 million positions listed as available in March, underscoring the continuing strength of the labor market.The number of “quits” — a measurement of the amount of workers voluntarily leaving jobs — also reached a high, an indicator that many workers are confident they can leave their jobs and find employment that better suits their desires or needs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Bangladesh Closes Dozens of Schools in Rohingya Refugee Camps
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 3, 2022.
content: “I want to be a doctor. But if our school remains shut, I don’t know how I will study.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Sydney Harper, Patricia Willens, Paige Cowett, Brad Fisher, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Mar-a-Lago Midterms
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has turned his Florida club into a shadow Republican Party headquarters. The elections will test his continued sway.
content: Unlike other former presidents after leaving office, Donald J. Trump has remained in the middle of the political stage — raising more money than the Republican Party itself and doling out coveted endorsements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: N.F.L. Finds No Proof That Browns Paid Hue Jackson to Lose Games
description: Lawyers hired by the league found no evidence that the team offered former head coach Hue Jackson incentives to lose games as he had publicly claimed.
content: The N.F.L. said that it was unable to substantiate claims made by former Cleveland Browns coach Hue Jackson that the team provided incentives as part of a plan to deliberately lose games to improve their position in the draft in coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘In a New York Minute’ Review: Love or Freedom?
description: This drama from Ximan Li teases time in telling the stories of three Chinese women living in a city that tempts promise but delivers frustration.
content: The promising first-time feature filmmaker Ximan Li embraces the twists of immigrant experiences in the drama “In a New York Minute.” Based on a short story by Yi Nan that Li adapted, the director braids the saga of three women living in New York City. While their situations are very different, the malaise dogging each of them overlaps. Visual intersectional hints and an errant at-home pregnancy test link the women in ways intriguing if occasionally, forced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian J. Rivera and Patrick Healy
title: What Your Younger Employees Are Really Thinking
description: Twelve millennials talked to Times Opinion about the Great Resignation, returning to the office and the workplace in America today.
content: They have political views but aren’t interested in talking politics at the office. Some like working from home and others prefer the office, but most agree that they communicate better with colleagues when at the office. They want bosses who give constructive criticism, but some think their bosses are scared of them. “They don’t want to hurt feelings,” a 30-year-old who works in auto sales said. Added a 33-year-old office manager, “You’re not going to hurt my feelings by telling me you’d like me to go in this direction or that direction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Reilly
title: Florence Welch Thrives on Horror. And She Still Wants to Smell You.
description: The Florence + the Machine frontwoman reveals what kept her motivated while working on the band’s next album: dancers, “Dracula” and daffodils.
content: Florence Welch thought she would be happy when the pandemic brought live music to a temporary end. For the past 13 years, after every tour, the shamanic frontwoman of the British rock band Florence + the Machine told herself, “I’m going to settle down.” Instead, she would write more songs — which is exactly what happened in 2020, culminating in her fifth album, “Dance Fever” (out May 13).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: Lionel Richie, Kate Moss at Prince Charles’s Gala
description: The Prince’s Trust held its first fund-raiser in the United States.
content: Prince Charles did not attend the gala for his own charity, the Prince’s Trust, held last Thursday at Cipriani South Street in downtown Manhattan. But there were plenty of other royals, both real and imagined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Eileen Sullivan
title: Cuban Migrants Arrive to U.S. in Record Numbers, on Foot, Not by Boat
description: Political repression and escalating economic difficulties on the island, along with a new visa-free travel policy in Nicaragua, are some of the factors driving the change.
content: Cuban migrants are arriving to the United States in the highest numbers seen in four decades, with about 150,000 expected to arrive this year, according to senior American officials, as the economic and political situation on the island grows more desperate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Much Gilt, Little Guilt
description: The Met Gala 2022 celebrated themes of opulence, excess and fame.
content: When “Gilded Glamour,” the dress code of the 2022 Met Gala, was announced, it seemed to be either a recipe for extravagant disaster or irony. After all, the current era has often been compared to the late 19th-century Gilded Age, that period between 1870 and 1900 when extreme wealth was concentrated in the hands of the very few, the robber barons came to the fore, and income inequality grew ever greater just beneath the gold veneer on the glittering surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Business and Roe v. Wade
description: After a Supreme Court bombshell, companies may find themselves thrust further into the political fray.
content: A draft Supreme Court opinion shows that a majority of justices voted in February to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark case establishing the right to abortion. The opinion, obtained by Politico, is still subject to change and debate up until its official release, which is expected by this summer. Regardless of the outcome, the draft is likely to have immediate consequences for business, thrusting companies further into the political fray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Go Ahead, Tell Me the Answer
description: Julian Lim has some history with this puzzle.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Julian Lim, who is making his 26th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Although Mr. Lim has had 26 puzzles published to date, this is only his second Tuesday puzzle, which may help explain why it felt a bit harder than your typical Tuesday — he’s usually a later-week kind of puzzle maker, used to spicier clues and wordplay!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Government Says Brittney Griner Was ‘Wrongfully Detained’
description: The State Department went public with its push to negotiate Griner’s release from custody in Russia, where she has been held on drug charges since February.
content: More than two months after the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner was accused of having drugs in her luggage and taken into custody in Russia, the U.S. State Department on Tuesday said that it had determined she was “wrongfully detained.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manan Luthra
title: Australian Gets 12 Years for Anti-Gay Killing of an American in 1988
description: Scott Johnson, a U.S. graduate student, was pushed off a cliff, in a case that was first ruled a suicide but that his brother refused to let go of.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian man who in January was convicted of killing a gay American doctoral student more than three decades ago by pushing him off a cliff received a sentence on Tuesday of 12 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers: Trump ‘Can’t Be Bothered’ to Endorse Republicans Correctly
description: “You have to grovel and debase yourself to earn the endorsement of a guy who can’t even remember your name,” Meyers said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small
title: A Dancer’s Farewell, Not as Choreographed
description: Abi Stafford Lillo left City Ballet amid a family feud and a dispute over whether a choreographer had body-shamed her or she lacked the strength to dance her final role.
content: When Abi Stafford Lillo took her final curtsy last fall after more than two decades at New York City Ballet, it looked like a typical dancer retirement, with colleagues handing her bouquets as the audience applauded wildly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 10 Senate races to watch this year.
description: Democrats have a razor-thin margin that could be upended with the loss of a single seat.
content: A single state could shift power in the Senate, where Democrats maintain a tenuous advantage by virtue of having the tiebreaking vote of Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Promised My Sperm-Donor Anonymity. What Do I Tell My Child?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on weighing a child’s interest in knowing her father against his desire for privacy.
content: A great friend of mine was the donor for my baby. At some point, I know my daughter will ask about her father, and I’m not sure how I will answer her question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Supreme Court in Disarray After an Extraordinary Breach
description: The leak of a draft majority opinion overruling Roe v. Wade raises questions about motives, methods and whether defections are still possible.
content: WASHINGTON — Sources have motives, and the leaked draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade raises a question as old as the Roman Empire. Cui bono? Who benefits?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Inflation bonds are earning eye-popping rates: 9.62 percent.
description: I bonds — low-risk savings bonds indexed to inflation — are earning far more than a typical federally insured savings account or certificate of deposit.
content: There’s not much good to say about inflation, with higher prices dogging consumers at the grocery store and the gas pump. But there is one bright spot: Government I bonds are earning eye-popping rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How Many Midcentury Ranch Houses Can One Couple Renovate?
description: These serial renovators in Dallas weren’t looking to take on another project — or even to move. But a white-hot housing market can inspire people to do unexpected things.
content: It all began with an unsolicited offer. After completing two renovations in Dallas, Ben and Josh Collins weren’t looking to tackle yet another project — until a real estate agent contacted them with an offer they couldn’t refuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Tale of a Crypto Executive Who Wasn’t Who He Said He Was
description: The chief operating officer of ZenLedger, a software company, boasted of work for Goldman Sachs and Larry King. Did anyone check to see if it was true?
content: When ZenLedger put out word of a deal in March for the Internal Revenue Service to keep using its software, Dan Hannum said he was “thrilled.” It was a big moment for the company, which has the backing of Mark Cuban and other investors as it aims to be a kind of TurboTax for crypto enthusiasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: John Waters’s First Novel Is Manic, Hyperbolic and Deviant. Surprised?
description: “Liarmouth” is about three generations of women in one family who plan to confront or kill one another. It also has a trampoline fun park.
content: In a recent essay for Gawker, Alexandra Tanner questioned why there are so many contemporary novels about “generations of women.” Often marketed as “sweeping or stunning, these books’ implicit promise to their readers, who are mostly women, is that they can, by reading them, understand what it is to be women from women,” Tanner wrote, observing that the premise, when abused, offers a spurious shortcut to poignancy and depth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Why the Supreme Court could overturn Roe v. Wade.
description: The landmark decision that established a constitutional right to an abortion has been contentious since it was made in 1973.
content: A majority of the Supreme Court has privately voted to strike down Roe v. Wade, according to a leaked draft opinion from February that was published by Politico. Here’s a look at the history of the landmark decision and the case from Mississippi now being decided by the court
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Colorado River Reservoirs Are So Low, Government Will Delay Releases
description: The decision will keep more water in Lake Powell on the Arizona-Utah border, instead of releasing it downstream to Lake Mead. Both reservoirs are at their lowest points.
content: With long-term severe drought continuing to take a toll on the Colorado River, the federal government announced on Tuesday that it will retain some water in one of the river’s major reservoirs, describing it as an extraordinary action to temporarily stave off increased uncertainty in water and electricity supplies in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: What Scientists Know About the Unusual Hepatitis Cases in Children
description: Officials are exploring the possibility that a common adenovirus might be responsible for the unexplained cases, which remain rare.
content: At least 16 countries and 10 U.S. states have either identified or are investigating reports of unusual hepatitis cases in otherwise healthy children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: ‘Mouth Almighty’ Doesn’t Mind When His Cheeks Are Full of Another Fish’s Babies
description: A study of Australian fish that care for offspring through mouthbrooding shows that things underwater are not always as monogamous as they seem.
content: Lurking among the underwater plants in Australia’s ponds and streams is a fish called the mouth almighty. The species is named for its impressive jaws, which snap up passing prey. But the males also use their almighty mouths to gently carry as many as hundreds of babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Leaked Draft Opinion on Roe Draws on Familiar Arguments
description: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. argued two basic points: The Constitution is silent on the question of abortion and Roe’s flaws make it unworthy of respect as precedent.
content: WASHINGTON — The draft Supreme Court opinion overruling Roe v. Wade is a sort of white paper prepared by the conservative legal movement long ago, awaiting only the arrival of a conservative majority ready to adopt it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: C.I.A. Captive Was Too Small for Waterboard, Interrogator Testifies
description: The former C.I.A. contract psychologist described both approved and unapproved interrogation techniques that he observed and carried out in the black sites.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The psychologist who for the C.I.A. waterboarded a prisoner accused of plotting the U.S.S. Cole bombing testified this week that the Saudi man broke quickly and became so compliant that he would crawl into a cramped crate even before guards ordered him inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘All My Puny Sorrows’ Review: Every Day, a Little Death
description: A sister tries to persuade a sibling that her life is worth living.
content: Late in the often dour family drama “All My Puny Sorrows,” adapted from a book of the same name by Miriam Toews, Yoli (Alison Pill) asks her mother, Lottie (Mare Winningham), if she’s heard of the poet Fernando Pessoa. After a moment’s consideration, Yoli, a writer herself, remarks that the poet killed himself. Lottie replies from over her tabletop puzzle, “Oh brother, who hasn’t?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Partisan Fight Breaks Out Over New Disinformation Board
description: The board, an advisory group with the Department of Homeland Security, has become embroiled in the debate over the government’s role in policing online content.
content: Nina Jankowicz’s new book, “How to Be a Woman Online,” chronicles the vitriol she and other women have faced from trolls and other malign actors. She’s now at the center of a new firestorm of criticism, this time over her appointment to lead an advisory board at the Department of Homeland Security on the threat of disinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Sidney Crosby, 17 Seasons On, Is Ready to Wreck the N.H.L. Playoffs
description: One of the league’s longest active players, Crosby quietly had an exceptional season. His Pittsburgh Penguins are in the playoffs for the 16th consecutive year.
content: TORONTO — The Pittsburgh Penguins are in the playoffs for the 16th consecutive season — the longest active streak of any team in the five major professional team sports in North America — largely because Sidney Crosby, their enduring star center, quietly had one of the best seasons in the N.H.L. at age 34.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Landon Nordeman and Elizabeth Bristow
title: Star Gazing at the Met Gala
description: An insider’s view of the fashion party of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Wan Wan, Focusing on Regional Thai Fare, Opens in NoLIta
description: A sake bar from Sushi Nakazawa’s finest, Brazilian in Midtown West, and more restaurant news.
content: Erika Chou, who owns Wayla on the Lower East Side and Kimika in NoLIta, has added this Thai restaurant to her portfolio, in partnership with Tom Naumsuwan, a Bangkok native, who will be the executive chef. In a setting with exposed brick, velvet banquettes, an Art Deco chandelier and touches of gold leaf, he will focus on regional Thai dishes, especially from Phuket, where there is a Chinese influence. On the menu are taw hu tod, a tofu dish with spicy peanut sauce; nun gai tod (crispy chicken skin with garlic and salt); moo tod nam pla (fried pork belly glazed with fish sauce); and a number of noodle dishes, like mee hok kien (stir-fried yellow noodles with mushrooms, scallions and fried kale). Cocktails like a pandan colada share the drink list with nonalcoholic choices, including the koh emerald, a refresher made with cucumber juice, makrut lime, dill, mint and soda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Frankies 457 Spuntino Plans a Nashville Outpost
description: The restaurant group will bring its brand of Brooklyn Italian fare to a new development in East Nashville.
content: Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, the owners of Frankies 457 Spuntino in Brooklyn, plan to open a location in Nashville, their first outside New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Wild Fox Kills 25 Flamingos and a Duck at the National Zoo
description: The fox, which escaped, had apparently gnawed a softball-size hole in the metal mesh surrounding the birds’ outdoor yard, zoo officials said.
content: When a curator of the bird collection at Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington came to work on Monday morning, she was startled to see a wild fox leaving the flamingo habitat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: New York City Pulls Plug on Second Homeless Shelter in Chinatown
description: The Adams administration backtracked on the second shelter, one of three that had been proposed for the neighborhood, after protests from the community.
content: For the second time in less than a week, New York City canceled plans on Monday for a shelter in Chinatown, where community opposition has complicated Mayor Eric Adams’s efforts to move homeless New Yorkers off the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Nicholas Fandos
title: Hochul Chooses Antonio Delgado as New Lieutenant Governor
description: Mr. Delgado is also expected to serve as Gov. Kathy Hochul’s running mate this year, replacing former Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul selected Representative Antonio Delgado as her new lieutenant governor on Tuesday, elevating a fellow moderate from outside New York City to be her second-in-command and running mate in June’s Democratic primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Missiles hit power stations in Lviv and along crucial railways in central and western Ukraine.
description: Altogether, six electrical substations were struck along the railways in central and western Ukraine, according to a top rail official. The rail system is the country’s lifeline for humanitarian and military supplies.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian missiles struck power plants in Lviv on Tuesday night, knocking out electricity in much of the western Ukrainian city near the Polish border where tens of thousands of civilians fleeing fighting in the east have sought refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Slow-Danced on the Sidewalk’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Emptying a drawer that for years had sat unsifted, I found old computer disks, a yellowed newspaper and a stack of senior photos of my first students. In our classroom in Watertown, Minn., these kids had watched me fumble with seating charts and desk arrangements, with lagging book discussions, with disrespect. And yet they wrote for me: poems and essays layered with declarations, confessions, errors and hope. I blinked over their bent heads, the sound of their shifting pencils speeding my heartbeat. Sometimes, one would glance at me. Yes, I’d want to say, I see you. I still do. — Emily Brisse
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Christine Baranski Is an Expert in ‘Gilded Glamour’
description: The story behind the red-carpet look.
content: When Christine Baranski’s character on “The Gilded Age” looks out her window at the mansion across the street, she sees the equivalent of a Trump casino.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Trump Settles Suit Over Payments to Hotel for 2017 Inauguration
description: The lawsuit brought by the attorney general in Washington, D.C., claimed that the Trump hotel accepted excessive payments from the inaugural committee.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump family business and President Donald J. Trump’s 2017 inauguration committee have jointly agreed to pay $750,000 to settle a lawsuit filed by the attorney general for the District of Columbia, who claimed that the Trump International Hotel in Washington illegally received excessive payments from the inauguration committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Quick Facts You Should Know About Roe v. Wade
description: A short history of the landmark case.
content: Nearly 50 years ago, the Supreme Court legalized abortion in the United States with its decision in Roe v. Wade, reshaping the nation’s social and political landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain and Joe Buglewicz
title: Where Lawns Are Outlawed (and Dug Up, and Carted Away)
description: With drought and growth taking a toll on the Colorado River, the source of 90 percent of the region’s water, a new law in Las Vegas mandates the removal of turf, patch by patch.
content: LAS VEGAS — It was a perfectly decent patch of lawn, several hundred square feet of grass in a condominium community on this city’s western edge. But Jaime Gonzalez, a worker with a local landscaping firm, had a job to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Hafner
title: David Walden, Computer Scientist at Dawn of Internet, Dies at 79
description: In 1969, he was part of a team of young engineers who built the first machine to switch data among computers using the Arpanet, the precursor to the internet.
content: David Walden, a computer scientist who helped develop a machine that would evolve to become the backbone of the internet for decades, died on April 27 at his home in East Sandwich, Mass. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Sister and Brother Choose Repertoire by Feeling and Listening
description: The young British phenoms Isata and Sheku Kanneh-Mason are performing a duo recital of cello sonatas, including by Shostakovich and Frank Bridge, at Carnegie Hall.
content: Are Sheku and Isata Kanneh-Mason those rarest of things: young superstars who might actually live up to their hype?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: J Balvin Is Trying Something New
description: The story behind the red-carpet look.
content: One night last fall, J Balvin, the reggaeton rapper, shared a photo of the back of his bare neck. Deep red imprints formed a kind of collar as if someone had tried to choke the Colombian superstar with scalding hot chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Reid J. Epstein
title: Overnight, Midterms Get a White-Hot New Focus: Abortion
description: Exultant Republicans planned new bans. Democrats, who have struggled to rally around abortion rights, hoped a bruising Supreme Court loss could jolt their voters into action.
content: A leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling overturning Roe v. Wade instantly propelled the debate over abortion into the white-hot center of American politics, emboldening Republicans across the country and leaving Democrats scrambling to jolt their voters into action six months before the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
title: Beijing tightens measures as some residents grow weary.
description: Authorities are trying to avoid a lockdown like the one imposed in Shanghai.
content: Residents in Beijing remained on edge on Tuesday as the authorities announced new measures to contain a small but growing outbreak of coronavirus cases, in an effort to avoid a lockdown like the one imposed in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: For Conservative Legal Movement, a Long-Sought Triumph Appears at Hand
description: For half a century, right-wing legal thinkers have been working toward the moment foretold by a leaked draft of a Supreme Court opinion.
content: WASHINGTON — In May 1987, Attorney General Edwin Meese III traveled to St. Louis and spoke before a group of clergy members opposed to abortion. Denouncing Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court’s 1973 ruling on abortion rights, he told them that he saw reason to hope that “in our lifetimes” it would be thrown on “the ash heap of legal history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Shawn Hubler
title: What a Roe v. Wade Repeal Would Mean for California
description: Abortion access is unlikely to change in California if the landmark law were to be struck down.
content: News that the Supreme Court privately voted to strike down the landmark Roe v. Wade decision reverberated across California on Monday night, eliciting outrage from abortion rights supporters and a sudden effort from top Capitol leaders to enshrine the right to abortion in the State Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Until Death Do Us Part, or Our Families Get to Know Each Other
description: In her new novel, “Love Marriage,” Monica Ali explores the ripple effect of one union on two households with deep secrets.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats Vow a Response to Roe’s Demise but Have Few Options
description: With neither the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster of legislation to protect abortion rights nor the 50 votes to pass it, Senate Democrats said they would try anyway.
content: WASHINGTON — With much of the Democratic Party raging over the seemingly imminent end to the almost 50-year-old constitutional right to an abortion, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York vowed on Tuesday to bring legislation to a vote that would codify a woman’s right to end her pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Judge Allows Part of Lawsuit by Tulsa Massacre Survivors Seeking Reparations
description: Three survivors of the 1921 massacre have sued the city of Tulsa, the county sheriff and other defendants over the attack, in which a white mob killed hundreds of Black residents.
content: Three survivors of the 1921 massacre that saw a white mob kill hundreds of Black residents and destroy a thriving Black business district in Tulsa, Okla., can proceed with part of a lawsuit seeking reparations, a judge in Oklahoma has ruled.
